This included:
* Code comments (javadoc vs. qt style) => doxygen: http://www.stack.nl/~dimitri/doxygen/docblocks.html * Code structuring (using special formatted headers with a top margin) * Line-breaks, line-length
etc.
I'm working on a qooxdoo/JavaScript Programming Conventions Guide. This will include comment style as well.

I would strongly prefer the Javadoc style. It is *much* more prevalent than the QT-style. JSDoc also uses this syntax.
Also a developer doesn't need to have a special IDE support for typing those stars. The opposite is the case: For the QT-style there will probably be never any IDE support available. For the Javadoc-style there is some support, I won't like to be missing. In JSEclipse for instance the attributes like @param are highlighted, which makes the comments much more readable. Also doc comments are highlighted in another color than other comments, which distinguishes them much better.

Another vote from me for the JavaDoc style.
I'm currently editing some existing qooxdoo comments (without the * characters before each line). Each time I press enter, JSEclipse puts a * at the start of the new line and I have to delete it manually. I think it's better to do it like everyone else (JavaDoc style) than to try and get JSEclipse to understand the qooxdoo syntax.
Have anybody out there found any possibility to let ultraedit support javadoc style comments. It just makes no fun to repeatly indenting with so many characters.
OK, through the migration to 0.7 all things will be upgraded to Javadoc.
now that we have migrated the code to 0.7 using a pretty printer we now have a unified coding style in the framework.
Closed all bugs already shipped with a release.
